hints_html:
There are three unknowns and we know 3 vectors on P, so plugging them in will give a 3 by 3 linear system that can be solved by Gaussian elimination.

However, this is not an efficient method. We know from part (b) that vectors lying in the plane P (meaning we can draw the heads and tails both in P) should all be perpendicular to the normal vector. Use this information to define an equation using dot product.

question: B 06 (c)
sols_html:
First pick a known vector on P. A convenient choice will be (0, 1, 2) (other vertices will work too).

Let (x, y, z) be an arbitrary vector on P (this represents all possible vectors on P, drawn with tail at origin and head on P), then the difference (x, y, z) - (0, 1, 2) gives a vector lying in P.

This vector must then be perpendicular to the normal vector, which gives the equation:

\[\begin{aligned} [(x, y, z) - (0, 1, 2)] \cdot (-3, -3, 1) = 0\end{aligned}\]

So

\[\begin{aligned} -3x - 3y + z = (0, 1, 2) \cdot (-3, -3, 1) = -1\end{aligned}\]

Dividing both sides by \(-3\) gives \(b = 1, c = -\frac{1}{3}, d = \frac{1}{3}\)

statement_html:
Consider the triangle T in three dimensions with vertices (0, 1, 2), (1, 1, 5) and (-1, 2, 2).

Consider also the plane P that contains T.

Write an equation for P in the form

\[\begin{aligned} x + by + cz = d\end{aligned}\]

with b, c and d to be determined.
